Can’t touch this: the impact of augmented reality versus touch and non-touch interfaces on perceived ownership
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • S.I. : Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality and Commerce
  • Published: 15 February 2018

Can’t touch this: the impact of augmented reality versus touch and non-touch interfaces on perceived ownership

  • Malaika Brengman1,
  • Kim Willems1,2 &
  • Helena Van Kerrebroeck1 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages269–280(2019)Cite this article

  • 1929 Accesses

  • 5 Citations

  • 5 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The rise of augmented reality (AR) technology presents e-retailers with new opportunities. According to previous research, it is a technology that can positively affect engagement, brand recall and purchase confidence. Mobile-enabled augmented reality differs from regular mobile phone use as the technology virtually overlays images or information to the real environment. As the use of a touch screen device (i.e. smartphone vs. laptop) has previously been found to positively affect feelings of perceived ownership, the current study examines whether the possibility to virtually manipulate a product on a mobile AR application would have an even stronger effect. This is examined for products with either material properties (i.e. products that require the examination of sensory information) or geometric properties (i.e. products that can be examined via written and/or visual information). The findings reveal that AR does indeed result in higher levels of perceived ownership, particularly in case of material products.

Introduction

Augmented reality allows for the digital overlay of content such as images, video, information to the user’s real environment. While augmented reality (AR) applications were first developed nearly four decades ago, the technology was not widely adopted due to a lack of dedicated devices. The pervasive presence of smartphones and other smart interfaces has increased the interest of developers and companies in recent years (Rese et al. 2017). Gartner predicts mobile augmented reality technology to become mainstream within the next 5–10 years (Gartner 2016a), and according to current AR app users, the breakthrough will even be within 1–5 years (Dacko 2017). As such, the potential of the technology in a marketing context has also drawn the attention of retailers (Mekni and Lemieux 2014).

In a marketing context various types of augmented reality applications exist (Javornik 2014). These applications can include interactive virtual try-on displays both in-store (e.g. virtual fitting room) (Pantano and Servidio 2012) and at home (e.g. jewellery or make-up apps) (Javornik 2014; Rese et al. 2014), or mobile phone product catalogue apps, such as the one offered by IKEA (Rese et al. 2014).

Although (mobile-enabled) augmented reality has been examined in the literature, it has not been done so extensively (Bulearca and Tamarjan 2010; Rese et al. 2017). Hence, this paper answers to the call for more research on mobile augmented reality (Pousttchi et al. 2015), as it can provide a pathway to further develop mobile markets. This study further explores the impact of using the technology for digital product examination on consumer behaviour. Recent studies have demonstrated the positive impact of augmented reality on, for instance, engagement (Javornik 2016b), brand recall (Mauroner et al. 2016), product likability (Verhagen et al. 2014), product tangibility (Vonkeman et al. 2017), product affect (Vonkeman et al. 2017), purchase impulsiveness (Vonkeman et al. 2017) and purchase confidence (Pantano 2014). While these studies demonstrate the value augmented reality can provide to consumers, no comparative studies have been conducted so far, contrasting augmented reality with other media without AR.

Also, up until now the concept of ‘perceived ownership’ has not yet been touched upon in relation to AR technology. Perceived ownership pertains to the feeling that a person ‘owns’ something, even though they are not necessarily the actual owner of the object (Pierce et al. 2003). Touching a product can enhance feelings of ownership (Peck and Shu 2009). In our current digitalized economy where consumers increasingly purchase online, touch is one aspect of the consumer experience that is not accounted for (Citrin et al. 2003; Grohmann et al. 2007; Verhagen et al. 2016; Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017). Investigating the impact of the medium (touch vs. non-touch) on perceived ownership, Brasel and Gips (2014) found that digital interaction on a touch screen with a product has a similar effect to actually touching it. As augmented reality allows for even more interaction (Javornik 2016b), the objective of this study is to determine the impact of augmented reality on users’ perceived ownership as compared to a laptop and touch screen mobile phone for inspecting both material and geometric products, as well as its subsequent impact on product attitudes and purchase intentions.

This paper is structured as follows: Sect. 2 provides a theoretical backdrop on augmented reality and its applications in marketing, as well as on the concept of perceived ownership and its implications for consumer behaviour. In Sect. 3 we propose our research objectives and hypotheses, followed by the methodology, which is elaborated in Sect. 4. Section 5 contains the analyses and results, which are discussed in Sect. 6, where the conclusions of this study are presented, highlighting some managerial implications, but also considering the limitations of the study and providing some suggestions for further research.

Literature review

Augmented reality

The rise of AR

Augmented reality integrates computer-generated imagery with the real world (Azuma 1997). It comprises of a “live, direct or indirect, view of a physical, real-world environment whose elements are augmented (or supplemented) by computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data” (Dacko 2017). As such, AR enriches a person’s sensory perception (Daponte et al. 2014) via enhanced interactivity (Milgram and Kishino 1994). When positioned in the mixed reality continuum presented by Milgram and Kishino (1994), AR is situated between the real and the virtual environment, leaning more towards the ‘real’ end of the continuum as there is still an interdependence with the real world (Mekni and Lemieux 2014).

In recent years, augmented reality has become available as an application for smartphones (Daponte et al. 2014; Gartner 2016b). According to Van Krevelen and Poelman (2010), this category of AR devices shows most potential to introduce the technology to the mass markets, to decrease production costs of the devices as no specific AR device is required and to improve ease of use of the technology by using a medium (i.e. mobile phone) already known to consumers.

Applications of augmented reality include military, medical, gaming and robotics (Mekni and Lemieux 2014; Spreer and Kallweit 2014), but also marketing applications show great promise (Mekni and Lemieux 2014).

Augmented reality and marketing

Augmented reality technology can provide richer (retail) experiences and more enjoyment to consumers (Blázquez 2014; Liao 2015). Applications of AR in a retailing context include, for instance, the augmentation of printed and digital product information with interactive content and the provision of information at the point of sale or in weekly promotional leaflets via the overlay of online information onto the product (Mauroner et al. 2016; Spreer and Kallweit 2014), virtual in-home furniture placements (Rese et al. 2014), as well as virtual try-ons for clothing or sunglasses (Pantano and Naccarato 2010; Verhagen et al. 2014), and make-up (Javornik et al. 2016). As such, the technology enhances the tangibility of the products (i.e. the mental representation of the product and its features as well as the perception of a physical presence) (Verhagen et al. 2016) and can enhance the digital shopping process.

According to Pantano (2014), AR has the potential to capture the attention of consumers. Augmented reality can be used by retailers to provide customers with virtual try-on opportunities, which can help them find the product they are most pleased with (Mekni and Lemieux 2014). In addition, the technology can provide additional product information (Baier et al. 2015), thus supporting consumers’ purchase decisions (Adhani and Rambli 2012; Javornik 2016b; Pantano 2014).

Recent studies have found that AR provides shopping enjoyment and less uncertainty and respondents are happier with their purchases (Dacko 2017; Spreer and Kallweit 2014). The use of a virtual mirror for sunglasses positively impacts users’ perception of product tangibility and product likability (Verhagen et al. 2014), while the use of a virtual make-up mirror provided users with an engaging and pleasurable experience that encouraged them to try out more colours (Javornik et al. 2016). In an advertising context, the interactive nature of AR technology positively affects brand recall and cognitive brand message processing (Mauroner et al. 2016). As such, consumers value brands and retailers that offer this technology higher; as the technology provides them with benefits, they normally would not get during their online (mobile) shopping experience (Dacko 2017).

Types of augmented reality and consumer acceptance

Various types of augmented reality technologies exist, namely those that are AR apps on smart devices versus AR on fixed interactive screens. AR on smart devices entails augmented reality applications that can be used on a smartphone or tablet, while fixed interactive screen AR applications pertain to, for instance, an in-store virtual try-on on a fixed screen. Based on a classification by Javornik (2016a), AR on smart devices and on fixed interactive screens is quite similar in terms of interactivity (i.e. responsiveness of the two-way communication between the device and the person; Song and Zinkhan 2008), modality (i.e. the diversity of content that can be presented; Sundar et al. 2012) and virtuality (i.e. the virtual elements that cause immersion; Steuer 1992). The level of interactivity for both smart devices and fixed screens is found to be medium to high. The modality of both devices pertains to video, text and image, and virtuality is considered to be at a medium level. Both device types do differ in terms of mobility (i.e. the possibility for mobile use; Varadarajan et al. 2010) and location specificity (i.e. the ability of a technology to target the user precisely via geolocation; Varadarajan et al. 2010), with location specificity and mobility being higher for AR on smart devices. A higher degree of mobility is advantageous to consumers, as they can use the application anywhere they wish (Javornik 2016a) and are not restricted to a fixed screen in the store. Moreover, the location specificity allows for more efficient use of AR applications in, for instance, the context of AR travel applications that provide additional information to tourists concerning tourist attractions. Moreover, using the smart device version allows for the user to use the AR application more privately and extensively as no one else will be watching or waiting their turn. When particularly regarding determinants of technology acceptance (e.g. Technology Acceptance Model; Rese et al. 2014), AR applications on smart devices will thus be likely to lead to higher levels of perceived ease of use.

A second classification of AR technology pertains to the interaction approach, which can be either marker-based or markerless. A marker-based application uses image recognition and often uses a logo or QR code in order to trigger the AR content (e.g. the IKEA catalogue or Auto Bild application; Javornik 2016a, b). A markerless application tracks the entire real environment and adds on the virtual content markerless (e.g. Homestyler, Mr. Spex or Ray Ban; Javornik 2016a, b). When using a marker-based application, for instance, the IKEA app which allows users to virtually place the furniture in their homes, the user is required to (1) have a catalogue to use as a marker, (2) place the catalogue correctly and (3) move the catalogue in order to move the digital product around the room. As such, the consumer is faced with the inconvenience related to the use of the marker (i.e. possibly not possessing the required marker, the time needed to move the marker around). A markerless system will not require the user to go through above mentioned steps. As such, a markerless application may be more convenient with regard to flexibility and may feel more intuitive (Carmigniani et al. 2011) and thus perform better in terms of the technology acceptance determinant ‘effort expectancy’ than marker-based technology (cf., UTAUT, Venkatesh et al. 2012).

However, markerless AR also presents limitations regarding the precision of the system (Carmigniani et al. 2011), as the placement of the virtual object in overlay to the real environment may not be a hundred per cent precise in the case of some AR technologies. AR make-up applications are an example of such markerless application that at times places the make-up in the (slightly) wrong position of the face (e.g. eye shadow being positioned too high above the eye). The technology that is deemed most appropriate thus depends on the type of content. In the case of, for instance, make-up or glasses, a very precise placement of the product will outweigh the burden of having to place markers, as inaccurate placement will diminish the usefulness of the application. Incorrect placement of the virtual overlay will also cause the information to be of less value. In another context, such as that of furniture, there is less reason to believe that a slightly inaccurate virtual furniture placement in a real room will have a large impact on how well a consumer will be able to picture the piece of furniture in that room regarding its style, colour, and size fit.

Perceived ownership

Perceived ownership—or psychological ownership—can be described as the sensation that something is “mine” (Pierce et al. 2003). It should be distinguished from personal/legal ownership, as the person who perceives ownership is not necessarily the actual owner (Pierce et al. 2003). According to developmental psychologists, this phenomenon dates back to our childhood (Furby 1980), with children often claiming that something is “theirs” while playing.

Perceived ownership translates itself into a reluctance to give up an object, as psychologically owning it is comparable to actual ownership, thus resulting in a higher valuation of the object (Kahneman et al. 1990). It is affected by the ability to control an object, knowing the object intimately or investing oneself in it (Pierce et al. 2003). Yet, it is not necessary for consumers to be very familiar with an object, as they can perceive ownership almost immediately (Kahneman et al. 1990; LeBarr and Shedden 2017). An important factor that does impact perceived ownership of an object is the ability to control the object (Rudmin and Berry 1987).

The impact of touch on perceived ownership

Our sense of touch is of major importance in sensory experiences (Krishna 2012). As such, it also affects human perceptions with regard to our evaluation of products (Spence 2011). For instance, Peck and Childers (2006) found that touch triggers impulse purchases. In addition, touch also decreases perceived evaluation difficulty (Laroche et al. 2005) and increases evaluation confidence (Peck and Childers 2003).

Research has also revealed that touch has an impact on perceived ownership, as the ability to control an object is partly affected by direct physical control (Furby 1980; Peck and Shu 2009). Peck and Shu (2009) found that touch positively affects the sense of perceived ownership.

As online shopping has an inherent inability to provide touch (Citrin et al. 2003;  Grohmann et al. 2007), previous research has investigated how this barrier can be overcome. Perceived ownership can be increased by providing actual touch, but also via ownership imagery (i.e. asking participants to imagine using the product or taking it home) (Peck and Shu 2009). In the absence of touch, haptic imagery (i.e. imagining touching the product) can provide an alternative approach, as more vivid haptic imagery positively impacts the perception of ownership (Peck et al. 2013).

The impact of the medium (touch versus non-touch) on perceived ownership

Given the importance of touch for consumers, in an initial exploration of the impact of various technology-based interfaces, Brasel and Gips (2014) examined the impact of touch screens on perceived ownership for a sweatshirt and a tent. The study considered a laptop with mouse, a laptop with touchpad and a tablet (touch screen). Touch interfaces were found to increase perceived psychological ownership, with the touch screen leading to the highest levels of perceived ownership. Similarly, Shen et al. (2016) found that a touch interface stimulates the respondent’s mental simulation of interaction with the product in the case of food.

These findings could be explained via the phenomenon of perceived touchability (Klatzky and Peck 2012) that suggests that users do not need to touch the product per se, but can be mentally stimulated to feel as if they have touched the product. In the minds of the users, the gesture of reaching out to touch the screen is highly similar to the gesture of reaching out to touch the product (Shen et al. 2016). Touch via a medium such as a mobile phone (e-touch) differs from directly touching products. While direct touch can be considered very important to certain consumers [e.g. high need-for-touch consumers, cf. Hoch (2002)], interacting with a product via digital media can serve as a valuable alternative for real touch sensations (Overmars and Poels 2013). On top of that, when hands are in close proximity to the interface (i.e. using a touch interface), users feel an innate tendency to inspect and manipulate the product (Coulter 2016), leading to higher ownership perceptions (Schlosser 2003, 2006).

Research objectives and hypotheses

While the impact of augmented reality in a shopping context has already been studied with regard to several consumer behavioural outcomes, the technology has so far not been tested with respect to its impact on perceived ownership, nor has it been compared to other media without AR. Yet, previous research has demonstrated that the medium consumers are using can affect their feeling of ownership towards the products they are viewing via that medium (Brasel and Gips 2014), which in turn can positively impact purchase behaviour (Balaji et al. 2011; Kamleitner and Feuchtl 2015). Given the effect of the medium on perceived ownership, it is worth investigating the effect of augmented reality. Augmented reality technology allows users to virtually interact with a product, by virtually touching the product on-screen, in overlay to their real environment (Javornik 2016a; Mauroner et al. 2016; Spreer and Kallweit 2014). Schlosser (2003, 2006) revealed that object interactivity in the context of virtual objects produces more vivid mental images. In addition, according to Rudmin and Berry (1987), one factor that strongly contributes to perceived ownership of an object is the ability to control the object. Given the interaction users can have with an object in AR and their immediate environment, it can be expected that the use of AR will lead to perceived ownership of a product.

The impact of AR on perceived ownership

As Brasel and Gips (2014) found evidence for their hypothesis that perceived ownership is higher when using a touch (versus non-touch) medium, this proposition is re-examined in order to validate this finding (cf. H1a) and extended to augmented reality in order to contribute to the existing literature. As augmented reality allows the user to virtually touch products and overlay the virtual image to one’s real environment, thus increasing the sense of product tangibility (Vonkeman et al. 2017), we expect (in H1b) perceived ownership to be even higher when using a mobile AR application as compared to a regular mobile touch interface (i.e. mobile phone), which in turn is expected to elicit higher perceived ownership as compared to a laptop:

H1a

Perceived ownership of a product is higher when using a touch screen mobile device than when using a laptop with mouse.

H1b

Perceived ownership of a product is higher when using a mobile augmented reality interface than when using a traditional touch screen mobile device.

The moderating impact of product type

Products can be categorized according to the relevance of touch, by distinguishing between products with geometric attributes (i.e. products with features that can be communicated reasonably well in words) versus products with material attributes (i.e. requiring physical inspection through our senses of touch and smell to examine the product) (Degeratu et al. 2000; Grohmann et al. 2007; McCabe and Nowlis 2003). Touch is as such inherently of more importance for material products than for geometric products (McCabe and Nowlis 2003). In their study, Brasel and Gips (2014) found that consumers experience higher perceived ownership for products with high haptic importance (i.e. material products, e.g. a sweatshirt) than for products with low haptic importance (i.e. geometric products, e.g. a tent).

Based on above findings, we expect the following:

H2

Perceived ownership levels are higher for a material product than for a geometric product.

In addition, we explore whether an interaction effect exists between the device and the type of product, as it is expected that perceived ownership levels will be higher for a material product when using an AR or touch device vs. a non-touch device. This relationship is expected to be less pronounced in case of a geometric product.

H3

There is an interaction effect between device type and product type on perceived ownership, with the effect being more pronounced in case of the material product.

The impact of perceived ownership on consumer behavioural outcomes

Perceived ownership has been shown to positively impact the attitudes towards objects (Balaji et al. 2011; Feuchtl and Kamleitner 2009; Gineikiene et al. 2017). In addition, in the same way that consumers that legally own an object value it higher, also perceived ownership has been demonstrated to be positively related to the value one attaches to an object (Peck and Shu 2009). As such, it has also been established that perceived ownership increases the desirability of a product (Fuchs et al. 2010) and ultimately actual purchase behaviour (Balaji et al. 2011; Kamleitner and Feuchtl 2015).

In line with these previous findings, we expect the following behavioural outcomes linked to perceived ownership:

H4

Product attitudes are positively impacted by higher levels of perceived ownership.

H5

Purchase intentions are positively impacted by higher levels of perceived ownership.

Methodology

Procedure

This study is based on a 3 × 2 full factorial experimental between-subjects design. The manipulations include three different media, namely a laptop with a computer mouse, a mobile phone with touch screen and a mobile augmented reality application, and two types of products displayed, namely a more geometric product (a design vase) and a more material product (a design lounge chair). The respondents were randomly assigned to one of the six conditions and were presented with a scenario in which they had to imagine that they were looking for a product such as the one presented in the condition. Participants could view the product as long as they wished via the assigned medium. Afterwards, a questionnaire was presented to them (cf. Section 3.4). All data were collected in a university laboratory setting in the summer of 2016.

Stimuli

The choice for the different products was made based on their diagnostic properties. Products can be categorized as having either material properties (i.e. characteristics that are best examined via touch) or geometric properties (i.e. products that can be examined through vision) (Klatzky et al. 1993; McCabe and Nowlis 2003) (c.f., Section 3.3). The products were chosen within the product range of home styling products, since this product category is particularly relevant to be assessed in the context of a real (augmented reality) environment (e.g. the IKEA AR catalogue app). The selected products were high-involvement, high-priced products (although prices were not displayed on the used website/app). For the material product, a design lounge chair (€599) was selected, as the softness and the feel of the material are of importance when judging the product. The geometric product is represented by a large design vase (€140), for which properties such as the shape can be identified by simply looking at the product.

With regard to the medium, respondents were exposed to the randomly assigned product via one of three media (either a laptop with a computer mouse, a mobile phone with touch screen or a mobile augmented reality application). For the laptop, respondents were exposed to the website pertaining to the product. Similarly, respondents in the mobile phone condition were exposed to the mobile website. Respondents in the augmented reality condition were exposed to the augmented reality representation of the product, via the AR app ‘Homestyler’.Footnote 1 In this condition, users could photograph the surroundings and then superimpose the virtual product representation in order to see what the product would look like in the actual space, or perform the same actions live. In doing so, users could manipulate the product on the screen (e.g. moving it around) to place it in the room.

Sampling and participant information

A total number of 277 responses were obtained in a student sample, of which 151 respondents were subjected to the material product condition (i.e. the design lounge chair) and 126 respondents were subjected to the geometric product condition (i.e. the design vase). A student sample is relevant in this empirical setting as the study focuses on personal opinions rather than an organizational context, and online shopping can be expected to be familiar to students (McKnight et al. 2002).

The average age of the respondents is 21.8 (SD = 2.05; range 18–29). An analysis of variance (ANOVA) indicates that the respondents were evenly distributed over the conditions where age is concerned (F(5270) = 0.869; p = 0.502). A Pearson Chi-square test (χ(10) = 5.627; p = 0.846) indicates that there is also an even spread of gender (50.1% male and 49.9% female) over the conditions (cf. Table 1).

Measures

All respondents completed a questionnaire pertaining to the constructs of perceived ownership (Peck and Shu (2009); 3 items; α = 0.940; e.g. ‘I feel like I own this [product]), attitude towards the product (Brown (1995); 4 items; α = 0.919; e.g. ‘unpleasant/pleasant’) and purchase intentions (Homer (1990); 2 items; r = 0.934; p < 0.001; e.g. ‘it is very likely that I will buy this [product]’).

The full list of items, measured by 7-point Likert scales (with anchor points 1 = strongly disagree and 7 = strongly agree), can be found in “Appendix 1”. For each construct, summated scale means are calculated for further analyses.

Analytical approach

In order to test hypotheses H1a, H1b, H2 and H3, first, a two-way ANOVA analysis is conducted to determine the impact of the type of product and medium on perceived ownership for this between-subjects design (Field 2009). As such, the medium (laptop, mobile phone and augmented reality) comprised the first fixed factor, while the type of product (material/geometric) comprised the second fixed factor. Second, post hoc LSD multiple pairwise comparisons provided further insight into the individual differences between the media (Brown 1995). Lastly, regarding the dependent variables ‘product attitude’ and ‘purchase intentions’, correlation analyses shed light on the impact of perceived ownership on each of these respective outcome variables (H4 and H5).

Analyses and results

As there appears to be no interaction effect (F(2271) = 0.078; p = 0.925), and thus no support for hypothesis 3 was found, the following discussion of the analyses will describe the main effects found. First, we describe the impact of the product on perceived ownership. Second, we describe the impact of the medium on perceived ownership. Lastly, the impact of perceived ownership on the outcome variables product attitude and purchase intensions is examined.

Impact of product and medium on perceived ownership

First, regarding the main effect of the type of product on perceived ownership, it was expected that perceived ownership would be higher for the product with material properties, for which touch is more important (H2). The 3 × 2 ANOVA reveals that a significant main effect on perceived ownership exists depending on product type (F(2271) = 4.554; p = 0.017), with levels of perceived ownership being higher for the material than for the geometric product, confirming hypothesis 2 (cf. Fig. 1) (mmaterial = 2.71; SD = 0.11; mgeometric = 2.38; SD = 0.12).

Second, regarding the main effect of the medium, it was expected that perceived ownership would be highest in the case of augmented reality, followed by the mobile phone, with the lowest perceived ownership pertaining to the laptop condition (H1a and 1b). The 3 × 2 ANOVA indicates that a statistically significant difference between the conditions exists (F(2148) = 6.156; p = 0.001). As is observable in Fig. 1, perceived ownership is higher in the case of AR. A post hoc analysis reveals that the difference between the two ‘touch’ media, mobile phone and AR, is significant (mAR = 2.93; SD = 0.14; mmobile = 2.32; SD = 0.14; p = 0.001). Similarly, a significant difference can be found between augmented reality and the laptop (mAR = 2.93; SD = 0.14; mlaptop = 2.38; SD = 0.14; p = 0.003). However, no significant difference could be discerned between the laptop and the mobile phone. As such, the findings are partly in line with hypothesis 1, as a significant difference can be found between AR and the other media (H1b), while no significant difference is found between the non-augmented touch and non-touch media (H1a).

Impact of perceived ownership on product attitudes and purchase intentions

The relationship between perceived ownership and product attitude is expected to be positive (H4). This is tested by means of a correlation between perceived ownership and product attitude. This analysis reveals that perceived ownership has a significant positive effect on product attitude (r = 0.312; p < 0.001; adjusted R2 = 0.094). Regarding each particular product type, we find that this positive effect exists both for the material product (r = 0.261; p = 0.001) and for the geometric product (r = 0.197; p = 0.027). As such, the findings confirm hypothesis 4.

Regarding the relationship between perceived ownership and purchase intentions, a positive relationship between both variables is expected (H5). A correlation analysis reveals that perceived ownership indeed has a significant positive effect on purchase intentions (r = 0.229; p < 0.001). Regarding each product type, the analyses reveal similar findings for both the material (r = 0.305; p < 0.001) and the geometric product (r = 0.325; p < 0.001). As such, the findings confirm hypothesis 5.

Conclusions

In what follows, we first discuss the results of the analyses with regard to the hypotheses. Next, we formulate managerial implications translating the findings from this study to insights for retailers. Finally, we discuss the limitations of the study and provide some suggestions for further research.

Discussion

The objective of this study was to determine the impact of mobile augmented reality technology (in comparison with a touch screen mobile phone and a laptop with mouse) on perceived ownership by means of a between-subjects experimental design, for both a material and a geometric product, as the impact of AR has, so far, not been tested with regard to product ownership effects. It was expected that perceived ownership would be highest for the mobile augmented reality interface, followed by the mobile phone, with the lowest level of perceived ownership in the laptop condition (H1). In addition, it was also expected that levels of perceived ownership would be higher for the material product than for the geometric product (H2). We also expected to find an interaction effect between the type of medium and the type of product (H3). Lastly, we expected higher levels of perceived ownership to positively impact product attitudes (H4) and purchase intentions (H5).

The results from the ANOVA demonstrate that in comparison with the laptop and the mobile phone, mobile augmented reality does indeed increase feelings of perceived ownership (confirming H1b), which is achieved by allowing users to ‘virtually’ touch the products and interact with them and is in line with other studies on perceived ownership (Rudmin and Berry 1987) and on AR (Mauroner et al. 2016; Vonkeman et al. 2017). Furthermore, this in turn positively affects product attitudes (confirming H4) and purchase intentions (confirming H5), which is in accordance with Balaji et al. (2011).

These findings hold equally true for both investigated product types as there appears to be no interaction effect according to product type (rejecting H3). As expected, perceived ownership indeed appears to be higher for the material product (i.e. lounge chair) as compared to the geometric product (i.e. design vase), and this for each of the media under study (confirming H2), which is in line with the findings of Brasel and Gips (2014).

While for both products under study, AR proved to generate superior effects in comparison to both the mobile device without AR and the laptop (confirming H1b), contrary to previous findings by Brasel and Gips (2014) no significant difference could be discerned in perceived ownership between the devices not offering AR technology, namely the mobile phone with touch interface and the laptop with mouse (rejecting H1a). Several explanations are possible for this deviating result. One possibility could be the size of the touch screen, as in the current study a smartphone was used, while in the earlier study a tablet was used. As the size of the mobile phone screen is smaller than that of the tablet, this may have eliminated the touch effect. On the other hand, there may also have been a novelty effect that may have faded away. At the time of the data collection of Brasel and Gips’ study (submitted to the Journal of Consumer Psychology already early 2013), touch tablets/phones were much more novel than now. The first introduction of the iPad was in 2010, and tablets were only expected to reach mainstream adoption in 2–5 years according to Gartner’s 2011 hype cycle (Dainoski 2013). Therefore, a novelty effect may have played in the previous study, which may presently be no longer in effect. Especially considering that both studies used student samples and smartphones have become very accessible and familiar to this younger generation, which was not the case hitherto. Moreover, unlike the study of Brasel and Gips (2014) who used a sweatshirt and a tent in their investigation, the current study used a home decorating augmented reality application for two types of products: a material product (lounge chair) and a geometric product (design vase), both relatively high-priced designer products, as compared to the more ordinary products focussed on in the previous study by Brasil and Gips (2014). In addition, the tactile properties of a lounge chair (i.e. material to sit in and chair softness) differ from those of a sweater (i.e. the feel of the material on the skin and warmth).

Overall, it can be concluded that a higher level of interaction with a product, by means of augmented reality, has a positive effect on perceived ownership, regardless of the product type (material or geometric), and that this in turn affects product attitudes and purchase intentions. As such, this study contributes to the academic literature, as it sheds light on the impact AR can have as compared to other media, with regard to perceived ownership, which has thus far not been examined yet.

Managerial implications

The findings of this study also provide some valuable insights for retailers. First of all, this study reaffirms that it may be interesting for them to invest in augmented reality as the technology can actually provide value to consumers (Javornik 2016b). Moreover, it is established that in comparison to non-augmented media, AR can lead to increased perceptions of product ownership, which leads to more favourable product attitudes and higher purchase intentions. This study also demonstrates that allowing users to examine products marketed online in more detail by digitally touching them generates perceived ownership which appears to be generally more pronounced (for each of the different investigated media) for products with material properties (i.e. requiring sensory information). Therefore, it is suggested that retailers should especially implement AR technology for products that require more than only written or visual information, but need to be inspected more thoroughly, which can thus also be done remotely. This could particularly be interesting for retailers selling apparel, certain types of furniture or even decorative products such as wallpaper, for which sensory input can be of relevance (Van Kerrebroeck et al. 2017).

Retailers interested in implementing AR should, however, take into account varying consumer dispositions towards new technologies. In that sense, markerless applications may be recommended, as they are more user-friendly and therefore generally more preferred (Rese et al. 2017). In addition, it is important to clearly communicate the benefits of using the technology to consumers and to provide them hedonic benefits as well during their usage experience (Spreer and Kallweit 2014). In terms of utilitarian value, augmented reality can serve to inform consumers about products by providing a marker on particular products or in magazines that allows users to view information or a video related to the product via AR, for example by showing recipes in which a product can be used (e.g. AR application of Heinz ketchup) or by providing digital try-on for particular products when specifically the size is important (e.g. clothing, jewellery, furniture placements). Such digital try-on, however, can also provide users with a fun experience (Javornik 2014) and thus can also serve a hedonic purpose.

Limitations and suggestions for further research

While this study offers insights into the merits of using augmented reality technology as a means to enhance feelings of ownership, some limitations must be taken into account. A first limitation of this study is that the data collection was done via a student sample. Results may differ when examining the effect of AR for an older age group (Rese et al. 2017) as older users may find the technology more difficult to use (Gurtner et al. 2014).

As the current study found no significant difference in perceived ownership between the mobile phone and the laptop interfaces, further research could examine why no such effect was found, as it contradicts the earlier study by Brasel and Gips (2014). For example, in a future study the screen size could be varied, to find out whether this is a determining factor or whether the previous findings were actually caused by a novelty effect and are only temporary. Further longitudinal research could also validate the current positive findings concerning mobile AR to verify whether they will still hold once AR technology has become more familiar and mainstream.

In addition, further research could also explore the impact of device ownership (Brasel and Gips 2014; Kirk et al. 2015), or the technology consumption context (i.e. private on a mobile device or in public via, for example, a virtual mirror) (Kirk et al. 2015) as device ownership and home usage may lead to higher levels of perceived ownership. Besides, the experiment took place in a classroom setting to control for the fit of the furniture into the environment. As device ownership may affect feelings of perceived ownership towards a product, repeating the experiment with respondents’ own personal device and even in their own homes may shed light on the impact of the test environment. We assume that the effects of domestic usage will be more outspoken, as in that case the actual fit in the own home environment can be assessed.

The current study focussed on a home decorating augmented reality application, considering two types of products: a material product (lounge chair) and a geometric product (design vase). Further research could also examine the impact of AR for different types of products, such as apparel (e.g. Vonkeman et al. (2017). Another possibility is to examine differences between product types such as hedonic versus utilitarian, as hedonic products are more probable to result in higher levels of perceived ownership (Dhar and Wertenbroch 2000).

While this research indicates that it may be worthwhile for online retailers to invest in augmented reality technology to allow consumers to virtually interact with the products on offer, further research may be required to determine the exact return on investment of the technology for such purposes.

Appendices

Appendix 1: scale items

Construct Scale type   Item Cronbach’s α/Pearson correlation
Perceived ownership (Peck and Shu 2009) 7-point Likert scale PO1 I feel like this is my [product]. α = 0.940
PO2 I feel a very high degree of personal ownership of the [product].
PO3 I feel like I own this [product].
Product attitude (Brown 1995) 7-point Likert scale PA1 Negative/positive α = 0.919
PA2 Unfavourable/favourable
PA3 Bad/good
PA4 Unpleasant/pleasant
Purchase intentions (Homer 1990) 7-point Likert scale PI1 Unlikely/likely r = 0.934
(p < 0.001)
PI2 Not probable/probable
